content.title: Cerebrospinal Fluid Drainage for Spinal Cord Protection
content.description: Lumbar cerebrospinal fluid drainage as a neuroprotective strategy during thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm repair to reduce spinal cord ischemia.
content.definition: CSF drainage reduces spinal cord ischemia during TAAA repair by decreasing intrathecal pressure, thereby improving spinal cord perfusion pressure (SCPP = MAP - CSF pressure). Standard of care for Extent I-III TAAA repairs.

mechanism: SCPP = Mean Arterial Pressure - CSF Pressure
Lowering CSF pressure increases effective cord perfusion
Compensates for reduced arterial input during aortic clamping
technique: Place lumbar drain preoperatively (L3-L4 or L4-L5)
Drain CSF to maintain pressure <10-15 mmHg
indications: Crawford Extent I, II, III TAAA (routine)
Previous aortic repair with intercostal sacrifice

learning_objectives: Understand spinal cord perfusion pressure physiology
Apply CSF drainage technique and targets
clinical_pearls: CSF drainage reduces spinal cord ischemia by >50% in high-risk repairs
Delayed paraplegia can be treated with emergent CSF drainage + hypertension
Avoid rapid drainage (>20 mL/hr) to prevent intracranial hypotension
Keep drain for 72 hours - delayed SCI can occur after initial normal exam
Argatroban or unfractionated heparin - avoid LMWH with drain in place
